description: Before the Oct. 5 elections in Brazil, candidates are creating jaw-dropping campaign advertisements to grab hold of voters’ attention and to stand out.
title: Brazil’s Politicians Often Play the Clown in Ads
title_page: Brazil’s Politicians Often Play the Clown in Ads - The New York Times
maintext:
RIO DE JANEIRO — An auditor flies through the air like Superman, shooting laser beams from his eyes. A clown channels the spirit of a septuagenarian pop star. A dermatologist concludes a tirade by simply screaming at viewers, “My name is Havanir!”
Yes, it is election season in Brazil, a vibrant democracy where fringe candidates are a resilient tradition and disenchantment with the political system is widespread. To cut through the confusion and grab voters’ attention, candidates are turning out some jaw-dropping campaign messages — advertisements that somewhere else might be mistaken for conceptual art pieces or the ramblings of unhinged minds.
“The neutral, generic method of appealing to voters is a mediocre and failed way of doing politics,” said Paulo Batista, 34, a real estate auditor and self-described libertarian who is running for a seat in São Paulo’s state legislature.
Mr. Batista’s ads, depicting him as a superhero using his laser vision to privatize dilapidated commuter trains, are popular on YouTube. And they are part of a thriving subgenre of ads drawing inspiration from the pages of comic books. Another recent example: the candidate for a Catalão City Council seat who dressed as Spider-Man and vanquished scoundrels in striped prison uniforms with well-aimed body blows.
